title: Erdős #45: Monochromatic Egyptian Fractions
description: For k ≥ 2, does there exist n_k such that any k-coloring of proper divisors D of n_k contains a monochromatic D' with Σ 1/d = 1? YES (Croot). Bounds: n_k ≈ exp(C^k) doubly exponential (Sawhney).

meta.author: Paul Erdős, Ernest Croot, Mehtaab Sawhney

overview.historicalContext: This problem connects Egyptian fractions (unit fraction representations) with Ramsey theory. Erdős asked whether highly composite numbers force monochromatic Egyptian representations under any coloring. Croot (2003) proved existence using probabilistic methods. Sawhney established tight doubly exponential bounds.
overview.problemStatement: Let k ≥ 2. Is there an integer n_k such that for D = {d : 1 < d < n_k, d | n_k}, any k-coloring of D contains a monochromatic subset D' ⊆ D with Σ_{d ∈ D'} 1/d = 1?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize proper divisors, k-colorings, monochromatic subsets, reciprocal sums, and the k-Egyptian property. Key results include Croot's existence theorem and Sawhney's doubly exponential bounds.
keyInsights: The answer is YES - such n_k exists for all k ≥ 2 (Croot)
Upper bound: n_k ≤ exp(C^k) using LCM of [1, C^k]
Lower bound: n_k ≥ exp(cC^k) from divisor sum constraints
Necessity: Σ_{d|n_k} 1/d ≥ k required, else greedy counterexample
Mertens theorem: minimal prime product requires primes up to C^k

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #45 on monochromatic Egyptian fractions. For any k-coloring of proper divisors of sufficiently large n_k, there exists a monochromatic subset with reciprocal sum 1. The bound is doubly exponential.
conclusion.implications: The result connects divisor theory to Ramsey theory. Highly composite numbers have enough divisor structure to force monochromatic unit fraction representations regardless of coloring.
openQuestions: What is the exact value of the optimal constant C?
Can explicit constructions replace probabilistic existence?
What is the smallest n_k for small values of k?
